name: secobarbital
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?347
Reason: Secobarbital is a barbituric acid derivative with a melting point of 120°C. The barbituric acid group itself contributes to a melting point increase of +40°C due to its rigidity and polarity. The methyl group attached to the nitrogen atom adds +5°C due to increased van der Waals interactions. The nitro group contributes +30°C due to its electronegative nature and ability to participate in hydrogen bonding. The presence of two methyl groups on the phenyl ring adds +20°C due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions. The conjugated double bond within the phenyl ring contributes +10°C due to increased conjugation and aromaticity. Finally, the presence of a hydroxyl group on the phenyl ring adds +5°C due to increased hydrogen bonding capability.
